headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for April 23, 2011.

headline: Asleep in the Tower
summary: The online buzz about air-traffic controllers dozing on the job.

headline: Fast Five: Women's Varsity Jackets
summary: The all-American varsity jacket is the warm-weather coverup a girl's got to have right now—whether it's silky, sporty or bohemian.

headline: Pastor Turns Focus to City Hall
summary: Terry Jones now pledges to hold a rally in front of Dearborn's City Hall to protest a court order barring him from demonstrating in front of the nation's largest mosque.

headline: Production Issues Suspected in Jet Rupture
summary: Investigators increasingly are focused on manufacturing-related issues, rather than a possible design flaw by Boeing, as they strive to unravel what caused the midair fuselage rupture of a Southwest jet earlier this month.

headline: Talent Trumps Desire as Rangers Exit Playoffs
summary: The Washington Capitals' elimination of the Rangers Saturday showed just how much work New York has to become a team built to go deep in the NHL playoffs.

headline: Protests Still Rage
summary: Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh accepted a deal that will have him step down from power after 30 days in exchange for immunity for himself and his close relatives as protests raged.

headline: Wildfires Burn in Texas
summary: State officials said Tuesday that a wildfire burning about 70 miles from the Dallas-Fort Worth area has blackened an area twice as big as previously estimated, and that strong wind gusts and hot temperatures would make it tougher to fight the blaze.

headline: For Christians and Jews, a Holy Week
summary: Around the world this week, Christians proceeded through the final days of prayer and fasting leading up to Easter and Jews marked the holiday of Passover.

headline: Qatargas, Centrica Sign LNG Deal
summary: State-owned Qatargas Operating Co. signed a sales and purchase agreement with U.K. utility Centrica to supply as much as 2.4 million tons a year of liquefied natural gas.

headline: Ugandan Opposition Party Wants Leader Freed
summary: Uganda's main opposition party, the Forum For Democratic Change, has asked the government to unconditionally release opposition leader Kizza Besigye from custody.

headline: Japan Commissions Inspection on Reactor
summary: The Japanese government's nuclear safety agency has commissioned an investigation into the ability of the No. 1 reactor at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi to withstand further earthquakes.

headline: Man Shops Net
summary: A duffel-load of new websites provide shopping-skittish guys with a reason to never leave the house again.

headline: East Village Old Country
summary: It's all about schnitzel for brunch at Edi & the Wolf, an East Village restaurant with Austrian roots.

headline: Air Controllers Press for Break-Time Naps
summary: The union representing the nation's 15,000 air-traffic controllers launched a campaign seeking federal approval for some of its members to take naps during breaks, setting up a clash with federal officials who oppose such a move.

headline: Notable Works, Plus Goo Goo Clusters
summary: Marshall Heyman attends two parties for New York women celebrating the release of a book and a film.

headline: What to Wear? Ask Edith
summary: "How to Dress for Success" assembles the advice of legendary Hollywood costume designer Edith Head, who dressed Elizabeth Taylor, Audrey Hepburn and Grace Kelly.

headline: Where Man Has His Place
summary: This week's photography reviews include exhibits that span the globe, from postwar Italian landscapes to grand Parisian organs.

headline: 'Evidence' in Ticket Fixing
summary: Mayor Bloomberg said investigators have uncovered "a lot of evidence" in a burgeoning probe that members of the NYPD helped friends and family get tickets dismissed.

headline: Thai Poll Fuels Fear of a Coup
summary: Tensions are rising in Thailand's capital city as army leaders accuse opposition politicians of being disloyal to the country's revered king and some residents worry that planned elections will be blocked, by a coup or some other means.

headline: Salad Is a Magic Word
summary: Salad names, breast-feeding bias and humpback whales go viral.

headline: Bypassing Microsoft, Again
summary: None

headline: Taco Loco Lawsuit
summary: A lawsuit that makes the case for "loser pays" tort reform.

headline: Lundqvist Doesn't Get a Nod for Vezina
summary: Plus Mike Knuble is out again for Saturday's game against the Rangers, and rainouts are piling up for the Yankees.

headline: Photo-Op: Astonishing Aerials
summary: Surfing photographs from the 80s when the beach bum's pastime became big business.

headline: Pricing Brightens for Paint Makers
summary: Just in time for the spring house-painting season, paint prices are heading higher, another example of rising commodity prices rippling through to consumers' pocketbooks

headline: Mets Tag Diamondbacks' Bullpen for a Win
summary: The Mets weren't able to solve starter Joe Saunders, but they knocked around Arizona's bullpen.

headline: It Was a Sad Death But Hardly a Surprise
summary: The brutal murder of the pro-Palestinian activist Italian journalist, highlighted in your editorial "A Death in Gaza" (April 16) only demonstrates the true nature of the radical fundamentalist Muslim groups,

headline: Tucker: Why I Still Support Nuclear Power, Even After Fukushima
summary: Coal plants must be fed by a 100-car freight train arriving every 30 hours.

headline: Last Chance for 'Spidey'
summary: The $70 million production "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark" is on hiatus as its new creative team overhauls the show, and if the revisions fail to bring it word-of-mouth and box-office success, its producers won't go back to the drawing board.

headline: Mightier Than the Sword
summary: The PEN American Center gathers the world's voices when they're needed most.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Columnist David Harsanyi says that more and more people make others pay for their votes as they become increasingly disconnected from the cost of government.

headline: The Fiscal Mirage of Raising Taxes on the Wealthy
summary: Regarding your editorial "Where the Tax Money Is" (April 18): President Obama has repeatedly stated that he will not raise taxes on the middle class, yet the devil is in the details.

headline: High Stakes in Dakotas
summary: The stakes are unusually high in North and South Dakota, where corn farmers are expected to play a crucial role in easing a national supply shortage.

summary: A top New York City schools official is one of two finalists for the next superintendent of schools in Newark, New Jersey's largest district and the focal point of the state's reform efforts.

headline: Do Women Control the Purse Strings?
summary: An oft-repeated statistic claiming that women control 80% or more of household spending isn't supported by academic research, economists say.

headline: Battered Dollar Gets A Holiday Reprieve
summary: The dollar got a respite Friday and could gain from a market correction early next week after being caught in a downdraft most of the week on U.S. monetary and fiscal policy deficiencies.

headline: Dollar's Decline Speeds Up
summary: The U.S. dollar's downward slide is accelerating as low interest rates, inflation concerns and the massive federal budget deficit undermine the currency.

headline: The Rembrandt of Sunset Strip
summary: A congenial nature has helped Paul Timman become one of the world's elite tattoo artists.

headline: Amazon Battles a Glitch in Its Cloud
summary: Amazon said technical problems with its Web-services business were lingering, but it expects the issues to be fixed later Friday.

headline: Spill Report Faults Transocean Rig
summary: Improper maintenance, insufficient staff training and badly designed safety systems may have contributed to last year's deadly explosion on Transocean Ltd.'s Deepwater Horizon drilling rig and subsequent oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: An Architect's Blueprint for Overexposure
summary: Joe Queenan on the Frank Gehry glut: With the architect's work everywhere, how about giving someone else a chance?

summary: Navy doctors in Afghanistan are experimenting with acupuncture and soothing atmospherics to treat Marines suffering from mild cases of traumatic brain injury.

headline: Alexander McQueen at the Met
summary: New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art offers a retrospective.

headline: China Drops Charges Against Lawyer
summary: Chinese authorities dropped the prosecution of a prominent defense lawyer days after releasing two other detained attorneys, an apparent attempt to deflect criticism ahead of human-rights talks with U.S. officials next week.

headline: William and Kate: It's Panic Time
summary: Samantha Bee offers her "tuppence" for the royal nuptials. For one, beware of bad hair-color jobs.

headline: Insurance Needs Its Own Regulation
summary: Your April 12 editorial "Systemically Confused" rightly points out that Washington's efforts to define "systemic risk" in the context of the Dodd-Frank Act have left many scratching their heads. You can count the insurance industry among the confused.

headline: Are Index Investors Getting Shortchanged?
summary: Indexing looks to be winning the battle for investors' wallets. But how much some of the latest converts are actually saving is far less clear.

summary: An exclusive preview of the upcoming book "The Wall Street Journal Guide to the 50 Economic Indicators That Really Matter."

headline: Biting Into Pizza That Costs Just Eight Bits
summary: Gray's Papaya, which has long lured New Yorkers with cheap hot dogs, recently ventured into a new arena: $1 slices of pizza.

headline: In Brief: 'Vienna Twilight'
summary: Psychoanalyst Max Liebermann and Detective Inspector Oskar Rheinhardt, the main characters in Frank Tallis's finely researched and elegantly written "Vienna Twilight," personify the clash of social trends in 1903 Austria.

headline: Condos Break Glass to Try Classic Style
summary: The owners of a 1925 building on upper Fifth Avenue are finishing a gut renovation while preserving the brick and limestone facade, the latest example of a developer trying to attract wealthy buyers with the allure of early 20th-century architecture.

summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of April 23, 2011

headline: Wildfires Scorch Lives on Texas Lake
summary: Nancy Ustick got the word that her small cabin on Possum Kingdom Lake, Texas, was in the path of wildfires that were consuming a vast stretch of the state. A week later, all that was left was a cement sculpture of a seagull that sat atop a dock piling.

summary: A look at some winning photographs from the Nature's Best Photography awards.

summary: They have the last word on their work schedule, including the notorious 2-2-1.

headline: The Generation Gap and Tax Refunds
summary: The implications of the generation gap, in attitudes about tax refunds, are far more pernicious than the poor financial planning underlying the phenomenon ("Refund Madness: It's in the Air," Weekend Investor, April 16).

headline: What the Nanny Saw; the Trouble With Men
summary: Sam Sacks reviews new fiction, including Francine Prose's "My New American Life," an immigrant story set in the aftermath of 9/11, and "The Summer Without Men," which ponders the question of man's inconstancy.

headline: Donald Trump's Favorite Golf Courses
summary: A hint: They tend to have "Trump" in their names. Plus, the Heritage Classic at Harbour Town needs a title sponsor.

headline: Please Treat Us as Individuals, Regardless of  Our Gender
summary: There aren't more executive women because women are rightfully more focused on home and family than their careers and they should stop clogging up our medical schools with their poor work ethics, ("Diverse Views on What Women Want in Our Economy," Letters, April 18).

summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group wants to use its restructured deal with Morgan Stanley as one way to enhance its commercial-banking interests in the U.S.

summary: Roughly a third of the filmmakers with work screening at the ongoing Tribeca Film Festival are women.

summary: That Easter egg hunt many are planning this weekend likely won't cost as much as last year. Consumption is on the decline, retail prices are falling and feed costs are going up.

headline: Pie Guy on Mend After Attack

summary: Syria's leadership, despite weeks of scrambling to appease and intimidate demonstrators, faced the largest outbreak of unrest in its four-decade rule, leading to the deaths of dozens.

summary: Suddenly, regulators are warning about financial clearinghouses.

headline: Giving to Caesar and Giving to the Poor
summary: Jim Wallis of Sojourners says that "Currently, 94% of funding for hunger programs comes from the federal government, while 6% comes from private donations" (Letters, April 19). Perhaps he might have said that 100% of all donations come from taxpayers.

headline: A Gumshoe Investor on Tech
summary: T. Rowe Price's Henry Ellenbogen values Twitter for its "sentiment data" but doesn't tweet. His fund is up nearly 46% since he took over a little more than a year ago.

summary: Corinne Ball serves on the board of Catholic Charities and has recently contributed about $35,000 to the organization; she also launched a group called Catholic Renewal which has raised $100,000.

headline: Best Buy Chairman Buys
summary: Richard M. Schulze recently bought 585,000 shares of the company through options exercises in a transaction valued at about $14.4 million.

headline: Toyota Signals a Bleak Year
summary: In a stark illustration of Japanese automotive woes, Toyota, the world's biggest auto maker by sales, says it doesn't expect to return to normal production levels before November.

headline: Manhattan Valley: Good Side of 96th Street
summary: Asking prices have been creeping up in the neighborhood north of 96th Street in recent years, but Manhattan Valley is less expensive than the southern part of the Upper West Side.

summary: In 1978, the future Nobel Peace Prize laureate Shirin Ebadi helped storm the justice ministry in Tehran in protest against the shah. 'The future appeared full of promise.'

summary: Inflation expectations have risen rapidly recently—but investors who place big bets on surging prices could get burned.

summary: Jonathan Franzen, Malcolm Gladwell, Karl Rove and Howard Dean are among the participants in cultural events this coming week.

headline: Foursquare Seeks Funds
summary: Foursquare is looking to raise fresh funds at a price that would value the location-based service at as much a $500 million.

headline: Calculating the Score
summary: Why are many athletes at institutions of higher learning unable to graduate? Is college basketball a national obsession? In "Big-Time Sports in American Universities," Charles Clotfelter examines the hold that athletic programs have over their colleges and what it means for those involved in the game. Fred Barnes reviews.

headline: Where Locals Know Best
summary: Who hasn't wondered about those dusty storefront travel agencies dotting New York's ethnic neighborhoods? Metro Money checks out a few of them and finds mixed results.

headline: Five Best: Looking at War From Many Angles
summary: David Mamet takes a kaleidoscopic survey of outstanding portraits of warriors' lives, from Frederic Manning's "Her Privates We," a novel based on his experiences in the trenches of World War I, to Ronald J. Glasser's "365 Days," a surgeon's view of the combat and combatants of the Vietnam War.

headline: Delta Lets Fliers Track Bags
summary: Delta has started letting passengers track the whereabouts of their checked bags, making it the first major carrier to offer such a service.

summary: Hearty but not heavy, navarin d'agneau showcases the season's first crop of vegetables and the delicate flavor of milk-fed lamb.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Writer Matt Gurney on politically correct Easter eggs.

summary: Built between 1949 and 1951, Mies van der Rohe's Farnsworth House instantly revolutionized country living and remains shockingly ahead of its time.

headline: Celtics' Onslaught Leaves Knicks Drained
summary: The Knicks, even with a healthy-enough Amar'e Stoudemire, couldn't handle the Celtics and now sit in a 0-3 hole in their playoff series.

headline: With Ice, Size Matters
summary: From shards to spheres, using the right shape can turn great drinks into extraordinary ones.

summary: Bye-bye, Buzz Lightyear and fairy-tale princesses—wall decoration for kids' rooms has gotten more sophisticated.

headline: The Sign Was There Before the Neighbors
summary: The complaints of the Hollywoodland Homeowners Association ("Hollywood's Famous Sign Elicits Few Hoorays From Its Neighbors," page one, April 20) reminds me of the guy who buys a house next to a golf course and then is upset when stray golf balls hit his roof.

headline: Shutter Fraternities for Young Women's Good
summary: Caitlin Flanagan looks back at a notorious University of Virginia sexual assault to make the case for an end to a Greek system that menaces women on campus.

headline: Volatility Index at Precrisis Levels
summary: The CBOE volatility index is below levels that haven't been seen since before the financial crisis, as strong corporate earnings and a rising stock market have calmed investors' jitters.

summary: The Celtics and Knicks have played over 400 games in towns that don't get along, but the rivalry only flickers and dies.

headline: After Soybeans, Corn's Flaky China Market
summary: As China starts to look overseas for corn, bulls may be too optimistic. An increase in imports isn't in doubt. Its extent and timing are.

headline: The Met's Rock of Ages
summary: Norman Lebrecht reviews "James Levine: 40 Years at the Metropolitan Opera," giving us a clear sense of the man who has already conducted more operas and performances than anyone in history.

headline: China Shares Slip; Tokyo Flat
summary: Asian stock markets were slightly lower in thin trading, with Japanese stocks dragged down by the yen's strength. Many markets were shut to mark Good Friday.
